comments.text:
+dee nunyofukinbidness If you are going to use logical fallacies at least 
use them correctly.

Slippery slope - Stating that something else will result form an action 
with any explanation or mechanism for said relation.  He did not commit 
this fallacy as he stated that the flaws in Marx's theories lead to abuse. 
 Even if you disagree with that assessment, it's enough to get him off the 
hook from the slippery slope fallacy.  

Ad Hominid - An attack on the person rather then the argument.  The 
beginning half of that statement doesn't attack your person hood, just your 
lack of evidence.  Although, the final "are you easy?" statement is an Ad 
Hominid.

Argumentum ad ignorantiam - Shifting the burden of proof.  While the "Do 
your own research" line is obviously a cope out, it's not shifting the 
burden of proof.  He did not state his position is correct until proven 
otherwise, rather he stated that he believes you should research the 
evidence.

A fallacy does not dictate whether a person is right or wrong, simply that 
there was a lapse in rationality.  If I stated that "legalizing gay 
marriage will result in bestiality" it's a slippery slope fallacy, because 
no connection between them was rationally given.  If I stated that 
"legalizing gay marriage will result in bestiality for reasons X, Y, and Z" 
it isn't a logical fallacy as rational was given (even if it is wrong). 
 Same with Argumentum ad Ignorantiam.  This means that the person doesn't 
understand who holds the burden of proof.  For example, stating "prove that 
dinosaurs DON'T exist" is an argumentum ad ignorantiam.  Conversely, 
stating that "Do research on dinosaurs" is not a logical fallacy.  The 
burden of proof wasn't actually shifted in this phrase, rather a command to 
investigate the topic.  The only "fallacy" being committed is assuming that 
research will automatically lead you to his conclusion.
comments.author: IngetKant

+MrMentalflossed Yes, the bribery will reduce a bit, but most of it will 
just be hidden. You're speaking like it was a hypothetical thing, that US 
experimenting with for the first time in human history. There are many 
countries (most of them actually) where this is illegal already. I'm not 
guessing on what will happen, I'm talking from the experience (for example 
in my country). Making it illegal is a good step and obvious one, but it is 
not THE solution. Death penalty won't stop people from murdering. Reality 
doesn't work like this. As well as 20 years prison won't stop other 
politicians to be corrupted. That's fairly naive. 

Further more, you think that "multi party" system won't help, because it 
won't stop politicians to be bought of. But I'm not disputing that. But 
bribing is not that easy. By having two fixed parties, you only have to 
bribe some much people and then you're done. You know that no other party 
will appear and you can't allocate much more money, because there's less 
risk. If on the other hand you had parties changing constantly because if 
the old ones were found to be bribed, then these corporations has much 
harder work. In combination with bribery being illegal, you might easily 
try to bribe a new politician, that will not only refuse the bribe, but 
will cooperate with police. So the risks are suddenly higher, and also 
there's flux of many people, and new ("unreadable") parties. Not only 
corporations have to do much more effort, but the failure rate will be 
higher. 

In the end imagine this. If, for example GOP politician - after bribery 
(money in politics) is deemed illegal - will be caught, the party will only 
exchange him. You'll never get a chance to remove whole party. Thus they 
have time over decades to devise the mechanisms for invisible bribery. They 
will always tell you, that that one politician was rotten apple, but the 
party stands strong. And you will believe, because it's not like you have 
another party to vote for. In our country, the parties are in fear of 
becoming obsolete, and this fear keeps them trying to be the best party. 
It's a free market competition. In the US, there are only two fat 
monopolizing parties, that have price agreements (cartel), and the voters 
are fucked. Enjoy.

I never said the 90's were great, I was using a measurement of time as an 
example.  The primary reason I used 1999 is because that's when gas prices 
were important to me, as that is when I was actually driving.  Its called 
personal experience.

The point is, I see essential services becoming more expensive, while only 
technology and optional entertainment-based services dropping in price.  
This means, things are easier for those who CAN afford it.  What about 
those who can't?

More personal experience.  I work my ass off, in jobs that not only require 
experience, but set skills that take years to acquire, yet still hover 
right on the edge of minimum wage, for my full-time job.  And for an 
additional 50 cents, I would load three times as much responsibility on my 
shoulders (which I have seen how stressful it has been, and continues to 
be, to others).  The backbone of the company, driving all sales that come 
from our location, STILL cannot have a liveable wage.

Is this fair?  Is this "paying people what they're worth"?  The ladder to 
success is missing its rungs, and we're left with nothing to climb, while 
MORE is piled onto our shoulders in increasingly demanding jobs that don't 
give you anything more for the greater amount of work you do.  And I see 
this same exact story over and over and over.

Nobody is asking that you pay no-skill jobs that require no experience more 
than minimum.  We are asking that you take into account what experience you 
require, what skills you require, what the job entails, how demanding that 
job is, and differentiate between someone who is working hard and someone 
who is half-assing it.  People should be paid for the work they do, and 
those who do more should GET more.  Its not entitlement, its "paying people 
what they're worth"

+Uruz2012 First of all, "IQ" and the notion of intelligence variation is a 
fabricated construct. Intelligence, the ability to derive cause and effect, 
only requires being conscious and having memory. There IS variation in 
people being right or wrong, but all correct opinions can be learned. The 
difference is that in a deliberative-system, all interested parties (which, 
I should have mentioned, will be able to be represented because the 
lottery-selected bodies only include applicants, i.e. people who are 
genuinely interested in influencing decisions in the subject matter at 
hand) would hear each other out (they'd have to attend to be allowed to 
vote) - maximally allowing compelling ideas to be proven and propagate, and 
disprovable ideas to be disproven. The scope for error in such a system is 
far less than the widescale fraud found in capitalism - for example 
psychiatric drugs are completely fraudulent products (along with the fraud 
of psychiatry itself), and whose basis is NOT sufficiently discussed 
because those who know about the fraud are effectively silenced by the 
profit motive to keep the fraud in place, keeping the sales in place but 
not actually helping people in real terms. A representative discussion 
would expose its shortcomings and offer real solutions instead. You miss 
the whole idea of a "qualification" - a "qualified" person should be able 
to EXPLAIN their idea to compel anyone, otherwise it's possible that their 
presumption isn't based on anything - so there is no justification for 
having any kind of self-appointing cult such as a "scientific class" or an 
"investor class" or any other type.
